Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Preoperative Home-Based Exercise Training on Quality of Life After Lung Cancer Surgery

Background: This randomised controlled trial assessed the impact of preoperative home-based exercise training (PHET) on quality of life (QoL) following lung cancer surgery.

Methods: Conducted across four hospitals in Portugal, patients aged ≥18 years with confirmed or suspected lung malignancy (stage IIIA or lower) were randomised 1:1 to PHET or control group (CG). PHET involved aerobic and resistance exercises with weekly telephone supervision. The primary outcome was QoL, measured using the EORTC QLQ-C30 at baseline, pre-surgery, and 1 month post-surgery. Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment in sealed envelopes. Outcome assessors were blinded. From September 2022 to May 2023, 46 patients were randomised (23 to each group).

Results: Intention-to-treat analysis included 41 patients (20 PHET, 21 CG). A significant group × time interaction was observed for global QoL (p = 0.004). PHET demonstrated statistically and clinically significant improvements in global QoL before (mean difference [MD], 13.5; 95% CI, 2.4–24.6; p = 0.019) and after surgery (MD, 12.4; 95% CI, 1.3–23.4; p = 0.029). Clinical deterioration in global QoL was reported by 71.4% of CG patients compared to 30% of PHET patients (p = 0.003). PHET also showed benefits in pain, appetite loss, and physical, emotional, and role functions post-surgery (p < 0.05). Adverse events were mild, with no serious events reported.

Trial registration: NCT05469425.

Funding: Not specified.
